awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of an Intensified KHz Rate Plenoptic Camera System for 3D Flow Diagnostics
awd_abstract_narration:
From blood flow through artificial heart valves to mixing and combustion of fuel and air in a modern jet engine, many flows are both unsteady and three-dimensional.  Modern diagnostics used to study, test and evaluate these flow fields, however, are slow and two-dimensional or, in the case of multi-camera 3D diagnostics, expensive and complex. In this project, the research team will develop a new imaging system capable of making high-speed 3D measurements in practical flow fields using only a single camera. The developed system will be significantly cheaper, more compact, and easier to set up than complex multi-camera systems, thus providing researchers around the world with an accessible and affordable tool to make high-speed 3D flow measurements. This imaging system will be used to understand cardio- and cerebro-vascular flows, advance high speed vehicle design research, and improve combustion efficiency in engines and combustion systems for power generation. In addition, the technology developed here will be openly shared with the broader research community to ensure access for students and researchers across the U.S. government agencies and industries. Such wide distribution ensures that the developed system impacts the widest possible range of applications involving unsteady, 3D fluid flows.

The basis for this diagnostic is an intensified plenoptic imaging system capable of measuring 3D scalar and velocity fields at framing rates in excess of 1,000 frames per second. The system consists of three essential elements: (1) a kHz rate intensified plenoptic camera and illumination source optimized for 3D flow measurements; (2) image reconstruction and velocity estimation algorithms to render volumetric images and estimate velocity fields; and (3) a computing platform that processes the data in an acceptable time frame. The development of this system will enable time-resolved, 3D flow measurements, including particle image velocimetry, chemiluminiscence imaging, laser induced fluorescence, and background oriented Schlieren imaging. The proposed instrument is based on a low frame-rate prototype built by investigators at Auburn University that has been demonstrated as a simple, compact, robust and effective 3D imaging system. The modularity of the system will allow the system to be optimized for different facilities and techniques, including stereo-plenoptic diagnostics with the potential to dramatically improve spatial resolution of volumetric measurements.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the development and construction of a novel, high-speed 3D imaging system for non-invasive flow field measurements.  Many flow systems of practical interest contain high spatiotemporal dynamics, where the measurement dynamic range is large, and where optical access to the flow may be limited.  The system developed here addresses this challenge through the concept of light-field imaging and consists of three main elements: (i) hardware: a kHz-rate plenoptic camera capable of visible-light and intensified UV-range 3D imaging, as well as a compatible illumination system, (ii) software: an algorithm to reconstruct the plenoptic images into 3D digital flow-fields, and an algorithm to estimate 3D velocity field thereof, and (iii) infrastructure: a computing platform that processes the data in an acceptable time frame. The novelty of the system lies in the design of the plenoptic camera, which operates similar to a conventional camera, but utilizes a microlens array placed between the main lens and the image sensor to resolve both spatial and angular information (i.e. 3D information) about a scene.  This enables time-resolved, 3D flow field measurements, such as tomographic particle image velocimetry, using a single camera, thus mitigating challenges associated with optical access and experimental complexity. Results suggest that this system can characterize 3D flow-fields within a 8?8?8cm3 volume at 1kHz acquisition rate. The system was designed to be modular such that future upgrades (e.g. faster, higher resolution cameras) will be straightforward to implement. The modular nature of the system also allowed for the incorporation of a UV-grade intensifier, yielding the first ever intensified plenoptic camera system. Two production copies of the kHz rate plenoptic camera system were built as part of this project with two additional cameras built under a separate program. In addition, three more systems are at varying stages of acquisition/construction by collaborators illustrating the growing impact and value of this instrumentation to the broader research community. To date, these systems have been deployed on the investigations of pipe-flow fluid dynamics, mosquito flight aerodynamics, spinning-golf ball flow, ctenophore (?sea jelly?) swimming dynamics, rotorcraft unsteady stall phenomenon, flapping-wing fluid structure interaction, solid rocket combustion pyrometry, additive manufacturing spatter measurements, and more.
